title: What is the Letwin agreement and will it pass?
text:
Sir Oliver Letwin has put forward an amendment that could block today’s Brexit vote. (Picture: AFP)

Boris Johnson has made a last-minute plea to MPs to pass his new Brexit deal ahead of a historic showdown in the House of Commons.

The knife-edge vote is set to take place this afternoon – but there’s a chance it may not go ahead at all.

The government announced this morning that they will send MPs home before the main Brexit deal vote if it the Letwin amendment passes.

Put forward by former Tory minister Sir Oliver Letwin, this would try to force a delay to Brexit until all the legislation implementing the new deal has been passed.

This keeps the Benn Act extension in place until all the legal boxes are ticked and would prevent an ‘accidental no-deal departure.’

The Benn Act was passed by MPs earlier this year, and forced the government to seek a three month extension to the EU deadline if no new withdrawal agreement was made before October 31st.

Analysts say the Letwin amendment looks likely to pass, with Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour and other opposition parties set to back it.

Advertisement

Tory rebels Philip Hammond, David Gauke and Nick Boles are some prominent politicians who have signaled they will back it too.

Supporters argue that were Parliament to approve the deal today, there might be a danger that the subsequent legislation to enact it might be somehow derailed, resulting in a no-deal exit on 31 October.

If the amendment does go through, the government will have to ask the EU for an extension tonight, following the provisions of the Benn Act.

That means the Prime Minister wouldn’t be able to put his deal directly to MPs as a binary choice between his deal and a no-deal Brexit.

Letwin said the amendment offers an ‘insurance policy’ that ensures there is an extension in the case the Brexit deal doesn’t go through in time.

He argues it will prevent the UK unintentionally crashing out without a deal.

Letwin says his amendment is an ‘insurance policy’ (Picture: AFP)

Earlier today, a number 10 source said if the Letwin amendment passes, EU Council President Donald Tusk will be given a copy of Parliament’s letter, but the government will continue to say to European leaders they want to get Brexit done on 31 October with the new deal.

BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg tweeted that if it passes, the government will try to bring meaningful vote on the whole withdrawal bill on Tuesday.

The Letwin amendment also invites the government to put forward a bill to implement their deal but with the opportunity for MPs to amend the bill.

If passed, it means MPs could try and amend it to make it harder or, more likely, softer.

In theory, it’s even possible that MPs could tweak it to make the deal dependent on a second referendum.
